author: catullus

0.0: To thee ( Cornelius !); for wast ever fain
0.1: To deem my trifles somewhat boon contain;
0.2: E'en when thou single 'mongst Italians found
0.3: Daredst all periods in three Scripts expound
0.5: Then take thee whatso in this booklet be,
0.6: Such as it is, whereto O Patron Maid
0.7: To live down Ages lend thou lasting aid!

1.1: Wherewith in bosom nurst to toy
1.2: She loves, and gives her finger-tip
1.3: For sharp-nib'd greeding neb to nip,
1.4: Were she who my desire withstood
1.5: To seek some pet of merry mood,
1.6: As crumb o' comfort for her grief,
1.8: Could I, as plays she, play with thee,
1.9: That mind might win from misery free!
1.11: To me t'were grateful (as they say),
1.12: Gold codling was to fleet-foot May,
1.13: Whose long-bound zone it loosed for aye.

2.0: Weep every Venus , and all Cupids wail,
2.1: And men whose gentler spirits still prevail.
2.2: Dead is the Sparrow of my girl, the joy,
2.3: Sparrow, my sweeting's most delicious toy,
2.4: Whom loved she dearer than her very eyes;
2.5: For he was honeyed-pet and anywise
2.6: Knew her, as even she her mother knew;
2.7: Ne'er from her bosom's harbourage he flew
2.8: But 'round her hopping here, there, everywhere,
2.9: Piped he to none but her his lady fair.
2.10: Now must he wander o'er the darkling way
2.11: Thither, whence life-return the Fates denay.
2.12: But ah! beshrew you, evil Shadows low'ring
2.13: In Orcus ever loveliest things devouring:
2.14: Who bore so pretty a Sparrow fro' her ta'en.
2.15: (Oh hapless birdie and Oh deed of bane!)
2.16: Now by your wanton work my girl appears
2.17: With turgid eyelids tinted rose by tears.

3.1: Saith she was erstwhile fleetest-fleet of crafts,
3.2: Nor could by swiftness of aught plank that swims,
3.3: Be she outstripped, whether paddle plied,
3.4: Or fared she scudding under canvas-sail.
3.5: Eke she defieth threat'ning Adrian shore,
3.6: Dare not denay her, insular Cyclades ,
3.7: And noble Rhodos and ferocious Thrace ,
3.8: Propontis too and blustering Pontic bight.
3.9: Where she (my Pinnace now) in times before,
3.10: Was leafy woodling on Cytórean Chine
3.11: For ever loquent lisping with her leaves.
3.13: Cognisant were ye, and you weet full well
3.14: (So saith my Pinnace) how from earliest age
3.15: Upon your highmost-spiring peak she stood,
3.16: How in your waters first her sculls were dipt,
3.17: And thence thro' many and many an important strait
3.18: She bore her owner whether left or right,
3.19: Where breezes bade her fare, or Jupiter deigned
3.20: At once propitious strike the sail full square;
3.21: Nor to the sea-shore gods was aught of vow
3.22: By her deemed needful, when from Ocean's bourne
3.23: Extreme she voyaged for this limpid lake.
3.24: Yet were such things whilome: now she retired
3.25: In quiet age devotes herself to thee
3.26: (0 twin-born Castor) twain with Castor's twin.

4.0: Love we (my Lesbia!) and live we our day,
4.1: While all stern sayings crabbed sages say,
4.2: At one doit's value let us price and prize!
4.3: The Suns can westward sink again to rise
4.4: But we, extinguished once our tiny light,
4.5: Perforce shall slumber through one lasting night!
4.6: Kiss me a thousand times, then hundred more,
4.7: Then thousand others, then a new five-score,
4.8: Still other thousand other hundred store.
4.9: Last when the sums to many thousands grow,
4.10: The tale let's trouble till no more we know,
4.11: Nor envious wight despiteful shall misween us
4.12: Knowing how many kisses have been kissed between us.

5.1: Were she not manner'd mean and worst in wit
5.2: Perforce thou hadst praised nor couldst silence keep.
5.3: But some enfevered jade, I wot-not-what,
5.4: Some piece thou lovest, blushing this to own.
5.5: For, nowise 'customed widower nights to lie
5.6: Thou 'rt ever summoned by no silent bed
5.7: With flow'r-wreaths fragrant and with Syrian oil,
5.8: By mattress, bolsters, here, there, everywhere
5.9: Deep-dinted, and by quaking, shaking couch
5.11: Explain! none whoredoms (no!) shall close my lips.
5.12: Why? such outfuttered flank thou ne'er wouldst show
5.13: Had not some fulsome work by thee been wrought.
5.14: Then what thou holdest, boon or bane be pleased
5.15: Disclose! For thee and thy beloved fain would I
5.16: Upraise to Heaven with my liveliest lay.

6.0: Thou ask'st How many kissing bouts I bore
6.1: From thee (my Lesbia!) or be enough or more?
6.2: I say what mighty sum of Lybian-sands
6.6: Or stars innumerate through night-stillness ken
6.7: The stolen Love-delights of mortal men,
6.8: For that to kiss thee with unending kisses
6.9: For mad Catullus enough and more be this,
6.10: Risses nor curious wight shall count their tale,
6.11: Nor to bewitch us evil tongue avail.

7.0: Woe-full Catullus! cease to play the fool
7.1: And what thou seest dead as dead regard!
7.2: Whilòme the sheeniest suns for thee did shine
7.3: When oft-a-tripping whither led the girl
7.4: By us beloved, as shall none be loved.
7.5: There all so merry doings then were done
7.6: After thy liking, nor the girl was loath.
7.7: Then certès sheeniest suns for thee did shine.
7.8: Now she's unwilling: thou too (hapless!) will
7.9: Her flight to follow, and sad life to live:
7.10: Endure with stubborn soul and still obdure.
7.12: Nor seeks thee, neither asks of thine unwill;
7.13: Yet shalt thou sorrow when none woos thee more;
7.14: Reprobate! Woe to thee! What life remains?
7.15: Who now shall love thee? Who'll think thee fair?
7.16: Whom now shalt ever love? Whose wilt be called?
7.17: To whom shalt kisses give? whose liplets nip?

8.0: Veranius! over every friend of me
8.1: Forestanding, owned I hundred thousands three,
8.2: Home to Penates and to single-soul'd
8.3: Brethren, returned art thou and mother old?
8.4: Yes, thou art come. Oh, winsome news come well!
8.5: Now shall I see thee, safely hear thee tell
8.6: Of sites Iberian, deeds and nations 'spied,
8.7: (As be thy wont) and neck-a-neck applied
8.8: I'll greet with kisses thy glad lips and eyne.
8.9: Oh! Of all mortal men beatified
8.10: Whose joy and gladness greater be than mine?

9.0: Led me my Varus to his flame,
9.1: As I from Forum idling came.
9.2: Forthright some whorelet judged I it
9.3: Nor lacking looks nor wanting wit,
9.4: When hied we thither, mid us three
9.5: Fell various talk, as how might be
9.6: Bithynia now, and how it fared,
9.7: And if some coin I made or spared.
9.10: Thence to return with oilier head;
9.12: Praetor, as pile the Cohort rating."
9.14: The custom rose, some men to bear
9.15: Litter thou boughtest ?" I to her
9.17: Cry, "Nay, with me 'twas not so ill
9.18: That, given the Province suffered, still
9.19: Eight stiff-backed loons I could not buy.'
9.20: (Withal none here nor there owned I
9.21: Who broken leg of Couch outworn
9.22: On nape of neck had ever borne!)
9.23: Then she, as pathic piece became,
9.30: But his or mine, it matters what?
9.31: I use it freely as though bought,
9.32: Yet thou, pert troubler, most absurd,
9.33: None suffer'st speak an idle word."

10.1: Whether extremest Indian shore he brave,
10.4: Or 'mid Hyrcanians dwell he, Arabs soft and wild,
10.5: Sacis and Parthians of the arrow fain,
10.6: Or where the Seven-mouth'd Nilus mud-defiled
10.8: Or climb he lofty Alpine Crest and note
10.10: Rhine Gallic, horrid Ocean and remote
10.12: All these (whatever shall the will design
10.13: Of Heaven-homed Gods) Oh ye prepared to tempt;
10.14: Announce your briefest to that damsel mine
10.16: Live she and love she wenchers several,
10.17: Embrace three hundred wi' the like requitals,
10.18: None truly loving and withal of all
10.20: My love regard she not, my love of yore,
10.21: Which fell through fault of her, as falls the fair
10.22: Last meadow-floret whenas passed it o'er

11.1: That hand sinistral in thy wit and wine
11.2: Filching the napkins of more heedless hosts.
11.3: Dost find this funny? Fool it passeth thee
11.4: How 'tis a sordid deed, a sorry jest.
11.5: Dost misbelieve me? Trust to Pollio,
11.6: Thy brother, ready to compound such thefts
11.7: E'en at a talent's cost; for he's a youth
11.8: In speech past master and in fair pleasantries.
11.10: Therefore expect thou, or return forthright
11.11: Linens whose loss affects me not for worth
11.12: But as mementoes of a comrade mine.
11.14: Fabúllus ent me a free giftie given
11.15: Also Veránius: these perforce I love
11.16: E'en as my Veraniólus and Fabúllus.

12.0: Thou'lt sup right well with me, Fabúllus mine,
12.1: In days few-numbered an the Gods design,
12.2: An great and goodly meal thou bring wi' thee
12.3: Nowise forgetting damsel bright o' blee,
12.4: With wine, and salty wit and laughs all-gay.
12.5: An these my bonny man, thou bring, I say
12.6: Thou'lt sup right well, for thy Catullus' purse
12.7: Save web of spider nothing does imburse.
12.8: But thou in countergift more loves shalt take
12.9: Or aught of sweeter taste or fairer make:
12.10: I'll give thee unguent lent my girl to scent
12.11: By every Venus and all Cupids sent,
12.12: Which, as thou savour, pray Gods interpose
12.13: And thee, Fabúllus, make a Naught-but-nose.

13.0: Did I not liefer love thee than my eyes
13.1: (Winsomest Calvus!), for that gift of thine
13.2: Certès I'd hate thee with Vatinian hate.
13.3: Say me, how came I, or by word or deed,
13.4: To cause thee plague me with so many a bard?
13.5: The Gods deal many an ill to such a client,
13.6: Who sent of impious wights to thee such crowd.
13.7: But if (as guess I) this choice boon new-found
13.9: None ill I hold it—well and welcome 'tis,
13.10: For that thy labours ne'er to death be doom'd.
13.11: Great Gods! What horrid booklet damnable
13.13: Did send, that ever day by day die he
13.15: No! No! thus shall't not pass wi' thee, sweet wag,
13.16: For I at dawning day will scour the booths
13.19: And with such torments pay thee for thy pains.
13.20: Now for the present hence, adieu! begone
13.21: Thither, whence came ye, brought by luckless feet,
13.22: Pests of the Century, ye pernicious Poets.

14.0: An of my trifles peradventure chance
14.1: You to be readers, and the hands of you
14.2: Without a shudder unto us be offer'd

15.0: To thee I trust my loves and me,
15.2: That (if in mind didst ever long
15.3: To win aught chaste unknowing wrong)
15.4: Then guard my boy in purest way.
15.5: From folk I say not: naught affray
15.6: The crowds wont here and there to run
15.8: But thee I dread nor less thy penis
15.9: Fair or foul, younglings' foe I ween is!
15.10: Wag it as wish thou, at its will,
15.11: When out of doors its hope fulfil;
15.13: But should ill-mind or lust's high jinks
15.14: Thee (Sinner!), drive to sin so dread,
15.15: That durst ensnare our dearling's head,
15.16: Ah! woe's thee (wretch!) and evil fate,
15.17: Mullet and radish shall pierce and grate,
15.18: When feet-bound, haled through yawning gate.

16.2: Who durst determine from my versicles
16.3: Which seem o'er softy, that I'm scant of shame.
16.4: For pious poet it behoves be chaste
16.5: Himself; no chastity his verses need;
16.6: Nay, gain they finally more salt of wit
16.7: When over softy and of scanty shame,
16.9: In boys, I say not, but in bearded men
16.10: Who fail of movements in their hardened loins.
16.11: Ye who so many thousand kisses sung
16.12: Have read, deny male masculant I be?

17.0: Colony! fain to display thy games on length of thy town-bridge!
17.1: There, too, ready to dance, though fearing the shaking of crazy
17.2: Logs of the Bridgelet propt on pier-piles newly renewèd,
17.3: Lest supine all sink deep-merged in the marish's hollow,
17.4: So may the bridge hold good when builded after thy pleasure
17.5: Where Salisúbulus' rites with solemn function are sacred,
17.6: As thou (Colony!) grant me boon of mightiest laughter.
17.7: Certain a townsman mine I'd lief see thrown from thy gangway
17.8: Hurlèd head over heels precipitous whelmed in the quagmire,
17.9: Where the lake and the boglands are most rotten and stinking,
17.10: Deepest and lividest lie, the swallow of hollow voracious.
17.11: Witless surely the wight whose sense is less than of boy-babe
17.12: Two-year-old and a-sleep on trembling forearm of father.
17.13: He though, wedded to girl in greenest bloom of her youth-tide,
17.14: (Bride-wife daintier bred than ever was delicate kidlet,
17.15: Worthier diligent watch than grape-bunch blackest and ripest)
17.16: Suffers her sport as she please nor rates her even at hair's worth,
17.17: Nowise 'stirring himself, but lying log-like as alder
17.18: Felled and o'er floating the fosse of safe Ligurian woodsman,
17.19: Feeling withal, as though such spouse he never had own'd;
17.20: So this marvel o' mine sees naught, and nothing can hear he,
17.21: What he himself, an he be or not be, wholly unknowing.
17.22: Now would I willingly pitch such wight head first fro' thy bridge,
17.23: Better a-sudden t'arouse that numskull's stolid old senses,
17.24: Or in the sluggish mud his soul supine to deposit
17.25: Even as she-mule casts iron shoe where quagmire is stiffest.

18.0: This grove to thee devote I give, Priapus!
18.1: Who home be Lampsacus and holt, Priapus!
18.2: For thee in cities worship most the shores
18.3: Of Hellespont the richest oystery strand.

19.0: This place, O youths, I protect, nor less this turfbuilded cottage,
19.1: Roofed with its osier-twigs and thatched with its bundles of sedges;
19.2: I from the dried oak hewn and fashioned with rustical hatchet,
19.3: Guarding them year by year while more are they evermore thriving.
19.4: For here be owners twain who greet and worship my Godship,
19.5: He of the poor hut lord and his son, the pair of them peasants:
19.6: This with assiduous toil aye works the thicketty herbage
19.7: And the coarse water-grass to clear afar from my chapel:
19.8: That with his open hand ever brings me offerings humble.
19.9: Hung up in honour mine are flowery firstlings of spring-tide,
19.10: Wreaths with their ears still soft the tender stalklets a-crowning;
19.11: Violets pale are mine by side of the poppy-head pallid;
19.12: With the dull yellow gourd and apples sweetest of savour;
19.13: Lastly the blushing grape disposed in shade of the vine-tree.
19.14: Anon mine altar (this same) with blood (but you will be silent!)
19.15: Bearded kid and anon some horny-hoofed nanny shall sprinkle.
19.16: Wherefore Priapus is bound to requite such honours by service,
19.17: Doing his duty to guard both vineyard and garth of his lordling.
19.18: Here then, O lads, refrain from ill-mannered picking and stealing:
19.19: Rich be the neighbour-hind and negligent eke his Priapus:
19.20: Take what be his: this path hence leadeth straight to his ownings.

20.0: I thuswise fashionèd by rustic art
20.1: And from dried poplar-trunk (0 traveller!) hewn,
20.2: This fieldlet, leftwards as thy glances fall,
20.3: And my lord's cottage with his pauper garth
20.5: In spring with vari-coloured wreaths I'm crown'd,
20.6: In fervid summer with the glowing grain,
20.7: Then with green vine-shoot and the luscious bunch,
20.8: And glaucous olive-tree in bitter cold.
20.9: The dainty she-goat from my pasture bears
20.10: Her milk-distended udders to the town:
20.11: Out of my sheep-cotes ta'en the fatted lamb
20.12: Sends home with silver right-hand heavily charged;
20.13: And, while its mother lows, the tender calf
20.14: Before the temples of the Gods must bleed.
20.15: Hence of such Godhead, (traveller !) stand in awe,
20.16: Best it befits thee off to keep thy hands.
20.17: Thy cross is ready, shaped as artless yard;
20.19: The boor, and plucking forth with bended arm
20.20: Makes of this tool a club for doughty hand.

21.0: Aurelius, father of the famisht crew,
21.1: Not sole of starvelings now, but wretches who
21.2: Were, are, or shall be in the years to come,
21.3: My love, my dearling, fain art thou to strum.
21.4: Nor privately; for nigh thou com'st and jestest
21.5: And to his side close-sticking all things questest.
21.6: 'Tis vain: while lay'st thou snares for me the worst,
21.7: By . . . . I will teach thee first.
21.8: An food-full thus do thou, my peace I'd keep:
21.9: But what (ah me ! ah me !) compels me weep
21.10: Are thirst and famine to my dearling fated.
21.11: Cease thou so doing while as modest rated,
21.12: Lest to thy will thou win—but . . . .

22.0: Varus, yon wight Suffenus known to thee
22.1: Fairly for wit, free talk, urbanity,
22.2: The same who scribbles verse in amplest store—
22.3: Methinks he fathers thousands ten or more
22.4: Indited not as wont on palimpsest,
22.5: But paper-royal, brand-new boards, and best
22.6: Fresh bosses, crimson ribbands, sheets with lead
22.7: Ruled, and with pumice-powder all well polished.
22.8: These as thou readest, seem that fine, urbane
22.10: Once more, such horrid change is there, so vile.
22.11: What must we wot thereof? a Droll erst while,
22.12: Or (if aught) cleverer, he with converse meets,
22.13: He now in dullness, dullest villain beats
22.14: Forthright on handling verse, nor is the wight
22.15: Ever so happy as when verse he write:
22.16: So self admires he with so full delight.
22.17: In sooth, we all thus err, nor man there be
22.18: But in some matter a Suffenus see
22.19: Thou canst: his lache allotted none shall lack
22.20: Yet spy we nothing of our back-borne pack.

23.0: Furius ! Nor chest, nor slaves can claim,
23.1: Bug, Spider, nor e'e n hearth aflame,
23.2: Yet thine a sire and step-dame who
23.3: Wi' tooth can ever flint-food chew!
23.4: So thou, and pleasant happy life
23.5: Lead wi' thy parents wooden wife.
23.6: Nor be this marvel: hale are all,
23.7: Well ye digest; no fears appal
23.11: Your frames are hard and dried like horn,
23.12: Or if more arid aught ye know
23.13: By suns and frosts and hunger-throe.
23.14: Then why not happy as thou'rt hale?
23.15: Sweat's strange to thee, spit fails, and fail
23.16: Phlegm and foul snivel from the nose.
23.17: Add cleanness that aye cleanlier shows
23.19: Nor ten times cack'st in total year,
23.20: And harder 'tis than pebble or bean
23.21: Which rubbed in hand or crumbled, e'en
23.22: On finger ne'er shall make unclean.

24.0: O of Juventian youths the flowret fair
24.1: Not of these only, but of all that were
24.2: Or shall be, coming in the coming years,
24.3: Better waste Midas' wealth (to me appears)
24.4: On him that owns nor slave nor money-chest
24.5: Than thou shouldst suffer by his love possest.
24.6: "What! is he vile or not fair?" "Yes!" I attest,
24.7: "Yet owns this man so comely neither slaves nor chest
24.8: My words disdain thou or accept at best
24.9: Yet neither slave he owns nor money-chest."

25.0: Thou bardache Thallus! more than Coney's robe
25.1: Soft, or goose-marrow or ear's lowmost lobe,
25.2: Or Age's languid yard and cobweb'd part,
25.3: Same Thallus greedier than the gale thou art,
25.4: When the Kite-goddess shows thee Gulls agape,
25.5: Return my muffler thou hast dared to rape,
25.6: Saetaban napkins, tablets of Thynos, all
25.7: Which (Fool!) ancestral heirlooms thou didst call.
25.8: These now unglueing from thy claws restore,
25.9: Lest thy soft hands, and floss-like flanklets score
25.10: The burning scourges, basely signed and lined,
25.11: And thou unwonted toss like wee barque tyned
25.12: 'Mid vasty Ocean vexed by madding wind!

26.0: Furius! our Villa never Austral force
26.1: B roke, neither set thereon Favonius' course,
26.2: Nor savage Boreas, nor Epeliot's strain,
26.3: But fifteen thousand crowns and hundreds twain
26.4: Wreckt it, —Oh ruinous by-wind, breezy bane!

27.0: Thou youngling drawer of Falernian old
27.1: Crown me the goblets with a bitterer wine
27.2: As was Postumia's law that rules the feast
27.4: But ye fare whither please ye (water-nymphs!)
27.5: To wine pernicious, and to sober folk
27.6: Migrate ye: mere Thyonian juice be here!

28.1: With your light budgets packt to hand,
28.3: What do ye? Bore ye enough, in fine
28.4: Of frost and famine with yon sot?
28.5: What loss or gain have haply got
28.6: Your tablets? so, whenas I ranged
28.7: With Praetor, gains for loss were changed.
28.8: "O Memmius! thou did'st long and late
28.10: But (truly see I) in such case
28.11: Diddled you were by wight as base
28.12: Sans mercy. Noble friends go claim!
28.13: Now god and goddess give you grame

29.0: Who e'er could witness this (who could endure
29.2: That should Mamurra get what hairy Gaul
29.3: And all that farthest Britons held whilòme?
29.4: (Thou bardache Romulus!) this wilt see and bear?
29.5: Then art a lewdling, dicer, greedy-gut!
29.6: He now superb with pride superfluous
29.7: Shall go perambulate the bedrooms all
29.9: Romulus thou bardache! this wilt see and bear?
29.11: Is't for such like name, sole Emperor thou!
29.14: Millions and Milliards might at will absorb?
29.16: What trifles wasted he, small heirlooms spent?
29.17: First his paternal goods were clean dispersed;
29.18: Second went Pontus ' spoils and for the third,—
29.20: Fear him the Gallias? Him the Britons' fear?
29.21: Why cherish this ill-wight? what 'vails he do?
29.23: Lost ye for such a name, o puissant pair

30.0: Alfénus! short of memory, false to comrades dearest-dear,
30.1: Now hast no pity (hardened Soul!) for friend and loving fere?
30.2: Now to betray me, now to guile. thou (traitor!) ne'er dost pause?
30.3: Yet impious feats of fraudful men ne'er force the Gods' applause:
30.4: When heed'st thou not deserting me (Sad me!) in sorest scathe,
30.5: Ah say whate'er shall humans do? in whom shall man show faith?
30.6: For sure thou bad'st me safely yield my spirit (wretch!) to thee,
30.7: Lulling my love as though my life were all security.
30.8: The same now dost withdraw thyself and every word and deed
30.9: Thou suffer'st winds and airy clouds to sweep from out thy head.
30.10: But an forget thou, mindful be the Gods, and Faith in mind
30.11: Bears thee, and soon shall gar thee rue the deeds by thee design'd.

31.1: Eyelet, and whatsoe'er in limpid meres
31.2: And vasty Ocean either Neptune owns,
31.3: Thy scenes how willing-glad once more I see,
31.4: At pain believing Thynia and the Fields
31.5: Bithynian left, I'm safe to sight thy Site.
31.6: Oh what more blessèd be than cares resolved,
31.7: When mind casts burthen and by peregrine
31.8: Work over wearied, lief we hie us home
31.9: To lie reposing in the longed-for bed!
31.10: This be the single meed for toils so triste.
31.11: Hail, O fair Sirmio , in thy lord rejoice:
31.12: And ye, O' waves of Lybian Lake be glad,
31.13: And laugh what laughter pealeth in my home.

32.1: My desires and my Wit the meetest,
32.2: So bid me join thy nap o' noon!
32.5: Lest thou be led afar to fare;
32.6: Nay bide at home, for us prepare
32.8: But aught do thou to hurry things,
32.10: And gown and tunic through I crack.

33.0: OH, best of robbers who in Baths delight,
33.1: Vibennius, sire and son, the Ingle hight,
33.2: (For that the father's hand be fouler one

44.0: O Farm our own, Sabine or Tiburtine,

44.7: Which not unmerited on me my maw,
44.9: For I requesting to be Sestius' guest
44.10: Read against claimant Antius a speech,
44.12: Hence a grave frigid rheum and frequent cough
44.13: Shook me till fled I to thy bosom, where
44.14: Repose and nettle-broth healed all my ills.
44.15: Wherefore recruited now best thanks I give
44.16: To thee for nowise punishing my sins:
44.17: Nor do I now object if noisome writs
44.18: Of Sestius hear I, but that cold and cough
44.19: And rheum may plague, not me, but Sestius' self
44.20: Who asks me only his ill writs to read.

45.8: (As wont) approving sneeze from dextral sped.

45.13: Unto one master's hest let's aye incline,
