63.0: Vesper is here, O youths, rise all; for Vesper Olympus
63.1: Scales and in fine enfires what lights so long were expected!
63.2: Time 'tis now to arise, now leave we tables rich laden,
63.3: Now shall the Virgin come; now chaunt we the Hymenaeus.
63.4: Hymen O Hymenaeus: Hymen here, O Hymenaeus!
63.5: View ye the Youths, O Maids unwed? Then rise to withstand them:
63.6: Doubtless the night-fraught Star displays his splendour Oetean.
63.7: Sooth 'tis so; d'ye sight how Speedily sprang they to warfare?
63.8: Nor for a naught up-sprang: they'll Sing what need we to conquer.
63.10: Nowise easy the palm for us (Companions!) be proffer'd,
63.11: Lo! now the maidens muse and meditate matter of forethought
63.12: Nor meditate they in vain; they muse a humorous something.
63.13: Yet naught wonder it is, their sprites be wholly in labour.
63.14: We bear divided thought one way and hearing in other:
63.15: Vanquish't by right we must be, since Victory loveth the heedful.
63.16: Therefore at least d'ye turn your minds the task to consider,
63.17: Soon shall begin their say whose countersay shall befit you.
63.19: Hesperus ! say what flame more cruel in Heaven be fanned?
63.20: Thou who the girl perforce canst tear from a mother's embraces,
63.21: Tear from a parent's clasp her child despite of her clinging
63.22: And upon love-hot youth bestowest her chastest of maidenhoods!
63.23: What shall the foeman deal more cruel to city becaptured?
63.24: Hymen O Hymenaeus, Hymen here, O Hymenaeus!
63.25: Hesperus ! say what flame more gladsome in Heavens be shining?
63.26: Thou whose light makes sure long-pledged connubial promise
63.27: Plighted erewhile by men and erstwhile plighted by parents.
63.28: Yet to be ne'er fulfilled before thy fire's ardours have risen!
63.29: What better boon can the gods bestow than hour so desirèd?
63.31: Hesperus ! one of ourselves (Companions!) carried elsewhither
63.35: For at thy coming in sight a guard is constantly watching.
63.36: Hidden o'nights lurk thieves and these as oft as returnest,
63.37: Hesper ! thou seizest them with title changed to Eous.
63.38: Pleases the bevy unwed with feigned complaints to accuse thee.
63.39: What if assail they whom their souls in secrecy cherish?
63.41: E'en as a flow'ret born secluded in garden enclosed,
63.42: Unto the flock unknown and ne'er uptorn by the ploughshare,
63.43: Soothed by the zephyrs and strengthened by suns and nourish't by showers
63.45: Loves her many a youth and longs for her many a maiden:
63.46: Yet from her lissome stalk when cropt that flower deflowered,
63.47: Loves her never a youth nor longs for her ever a maiden:
63.48: Thus while the virgin be whole, such while she's the dearling of kinsfolk;
63.49: Yet no sooner is lost her bloom from body polluted,
63.50: Neither to youths she is joy, nor a dearling she to the maidens.
63.52: E'en as an unmated vine which born in field of the barest
63.53: Never upraises head nor breeds the mellowy grape-bunch,
63.54: But under weight prone-bowed that tender body a-bending
63.55: Makes she her root anon to touch her topmost of tendrils;
63.56: Tends her never a hind nor tends her ever a herdsman:
63.57: Yet if haply conjoined the same with elm as a husband,
63.58: Tends her many a hind and tends her many a herdsman:
63.59: Thus is the maid when whole, uncultured waxes she aged;
63.60: But whenas union meet she wins her at ripest of seasons,
63.61: More to her spouse she is dear and less she's irk to her parents.
63.63: But do thou cease to resist (O Maid!) such bridegroom opposing,
63.64: Right it is not to resist whereto consigned thee a father,
63.65: Father and mother of thee unto whom obedience is owing.
63.66: Not is that maidenhood all thine own, but partly thy parents!
63.67: Owneth thy sire one third, one third is right of thy mother,
63.68: Only the third is thine: stint thee to strive with the others,
63.69: Who to the stranger son have yielded their dues with a dower!

64.0: O'er high deep seas in speedy ship his voyage Atys sped
64.1: Until he trod the Phrygian grove with hurried eager tread
64.2: And as the gloomy tree-shorn stead, the she-god's home, he sought
64.3: There sorely stung with fiery ire and madman's vaguing thought,
64.4: Share he with sharpened flint the freight wherewith his form was fraught.
64.5: Then as the she-he sensed limbs were void of manly strain
64.6: And sighted freshly shed a-ground spot of ensanguined stain,
64.7: Snatched she the timbrel's legier load with hands as snowdrops white,
64.8: Thy timbrel, Mother Cybele, the firstings of thy rite,
64.9: And as her tender finger-tips on bull-back hollow rang
64.10: She rose a-grieving and her song to listening comrades sang.
64.11: "Up Gallae, hie together, haste for Cybele's deep grove,
64.12: Hie to the Dindymnean dame, ye flocks that love to rove;
64.13: The which affecting stranger steads as bound in exile's brunt
64.14: My sect pursuing led by me have nerved you to confront
64.15: The raging surge of salty sea and ocean's tyrant hand
64.16: As your hate of Venus ' hest your manly forms unmann'd,
64.17: Gladden your souls, ye mistresses, with sense of error bann'd.
64.18: Drive from your spirits dull delay, together follow ye
64.19: To hold of Phrygian goddess, home of Phrygian Cybebe,
64.20: Where loud the cymbal's voice resounds with timbrel-echoes blending,
64.21: And where the Phrygian piper drones grave bass from reed a-bending,
64.22: Where toss their ivy-circled heads with might the Maenades
64.23: Where ply mid shrilly lullilooes the holiest mysteries,
64.24: Where to fly here and there be wont the she-god's vaguing train,
64.25: Thither behoves us lead the dance in quick-step hasty strain."
64.26: Soon as had Atys (bastard-she) this lay to comrades sung
64.27: The Chorus sudden lulliloos with quivering, quavering tongue,
64.28: Again the nimble timbrel groans, the scooped-out cymbals clash,
64.29: And up green Ida flits the Choir, with footsteps hurrying rash
64.30: Then Atys frantic, panting, raves, a-wandering, lost, insane,
64.31: And leads with timbrel hent and treads the shades where shadows rain,
64.32: Like heifer spurning load of yoke in yet unbroken pride;
64.33: And the swift Gallae follow fain their first and fleet-foot guide.
64.34: But when the home of Cybele they make with toil out-worn
64.35: O'er much, they lay them down to sleep and gifts of Ceres scorn;
64.36: Till heavy slumbers seal their eyelids langourous, drooping lowly,
64.37: And raving frenzy flies each brain departing softly, slowly.
64.38: But when Dan Sol with radiant eyes that fire his face of gold
64.39: Surveyed white aether and solid soil and waters uncontrol'd,
64.40: And chased with steeds sonorous-hooved the shades of lingering night,
64.41: Then sleep from waking Atys fled fleeting with sudden flight,
64.42: By Nymph Pasithae welcomed to palpitating breast.
64.43: Thus when his frenzy raging rash was soothed to gentlest rest,
64.44: Atys revolved deeds lately done, as thought from breast unfolding,
64.45: And what he'd lost and what he was with lucid sprite beholding,
64.46: To shallows led by surging soul again the way 'gan take.
64.47: There casting glance of weeping eyes where vasty billows brake,
64.48: Sad-voiced in pitifullest lay his native land bespake.
64.49: "Country of me, Creatress mine, born to thee and bred,
64.50: By hapless me abandoned as by thrall from lordling fled,
64.51: When me to Ida's groves and glades these vaguing footsteps bore
64.52: To tarry 'mid the snows and where lurk beasts in antres frore
64.53: And seek the deeply hidden lairs where furious ferals meet!
64.54: Where, Country! whither placed must I now hold thy site and seat?
64.55: Lief would these balls of eyes direct to thee their line of sight,
64.56: Which for a while, a little while, would free me from despite.
64.57: Must I for ever roam these groves from house and home afar?
64.58: Of country, parents, kith and kin (life's boon) myself debar?
64.59: Fly Forum, fly Palestra, fly the Stadium, the Gymnase?
64.60: Wretch, ah poor wretch, I'm doomed (my soul!) to mourn throughout my days,
64.61: For what of form or figure is, which I failed to enjoy?
64.62: I full-grown man, I blooming youth, I stripling, I a boy,
64.63: I of Gymnasium erst the bloom, I too of oil the pride:
64.64: Warm was my threshold, ever stood my gateways opening wide,
64.65: My house was ever garlanded and hung with flowery freight,
64.66: And couch to quit with rising sun, has ever been my fate:
64.67: Now must I Cybele's she-slave, priestess of gods, be hight?
64.68: I Maenad I, mere bit of self, I neutral barren wight?
64.69: I spend my life-tide couch't beneath high-towering Phrygian peaks?
64.70: I dwell on Ida's verdant slopes mottled with snowy streaks,
64.71: Where homes the forest-haunting doe, where roams the wildling boar?
64.72: Now, now I rue my deed foredone, now, now it irks me sore!"
64.73: Whenas from out those roseate lips these accents rapid flew,
64.74: Bore them to ears divine consigned a Nuncio true and new;
64.75: Then Cybele her lions twain disjoining from their yoke
64.76: The left-hand enemy of the herds a-goading thus bespoke:
64.77: "Up feral fell! up, hie with him, see rage his foot-steps urge,
64.78: See that his fury smite him till he seek the forest verge,
64.79: He who with over-freedom fain would fly mine empery.
64.80: Go, slash thy flank with lashing tail and sense the strokes of thee,
64.81: Make the whole mountain to thy roar sound and resound again,
64.82: And fiercely toss thy brawny neck that bears the tawny mane!"
64.83: So quoth an angered Cybele, and yoke with hand untied:
64.84: The feral rose in fiery wrath and self-inciting hied,
64.85: A-charging, roaring through the brake with breaking paws he tore.
64.86: But when he reached the humid sands where surges cream the shore,
64.87: Spying soft Atys lingering near the marbled pave of sea
64.88: He springs: the terror-madded wretch back to the wood doth flee,
64.89: Where for the remnant of her days a bondmaid's life led she.
64.90: Great Goddess, Goddess Cybele, Dindymus dame divine,
64.91: Far from my house and home thy wrath and wrack, dread mistress mine:
64.92: Goad others on with Fury's goad, others to Ire consign!

65.0: Pine-trees gendered whilome upon soaring Peliac summit
65.1: Swam (as the tale is told) through liquid surges of Neptune
65.2: Far as the Phasis-flood and frontier-land Aeetean;
65.3: Whenas the youths elect, of Argive vigour the oak-heart,
65.4: Longing the Golden Fleece of the Colchis-region to harry,
65.5: Dared in a poop swift-paced to span salt seas and their shallows,
65.6: Sweeping the deep blue seas with sweeps a-carven of fir-wood.
65.7: She, that governing Goddess of citadels crowning the cities,
65.8: Builded herself their car fast-flitting with lightest of breezes,
65.9: Weaving plants of the pine conjoined in curve of the kelson;
65.10: Foremost of all to imbue rude Amphitrite with ship-lore.
65.11: Soon as her beak had burst through wind-rackt spaces of ocean,
65.12: While the oar-tortured wave with spumy whiteness was blanching,
65.13: Surged from the deep abyss and hoar-capped billows the faces
65.14: Seaborn, Nereids eyeing the prodigy wonder-smitten.
65.15: There too mortal orbs through softened spendours regarded
65.16: Ocean-nymphs who exposed bodies denuded of raiment
65.17: Bare to the breast upthrust from hoar froth capping the sea-depths.
65.18: Then Thetis Peleus fired (men say) a-sudden with love,
65.19: Then Thetis nowise spurned to mate and marry with mortal,
65.20: Then Thetis' Sire himself her yoke with Peleus sanctioned.
65.21: Oh, in those happier days now fondly yearned-for, you heroes
65.22: Born; (all hail!) of the gods begotten, and excellent issue
65.23: Bred by your mothers, all hail! and placid deal me your favour.
65.24: Oft with the sound of me, in strains and spells I'll invoke you;
65.25: You too by wedding-torch so happily, highly augmented,
65.26: Peleus, Thessaly 's ward, in whose favor Jupiter himself,
65.27: The Father of the gods, resigned his passions.
65.28: You Thetis, fairest of maids Nereian, vouchsafed to marry?
65.29: You did Tethys empower to woo and wed with her grandchild;
65.30: Nor less Oceanus, with water compassing th' Earth-globe?
65.31: But when ended the term, and wisht-for light of the day-tide
65.32: Uprose, flocks to the house in concourse mighty, convened,
65.33: Thessaly all, with glad assembly the Palace fulfilling:
65.34: Presents afore they bring, and joy in faces declare they.
65.35: Cieros abides a desert: they quit Phthiotican Tempe,
65.36: Homesteads of Crannon-town, eke bulwarkt walls Larissa;
65.37: Meeting at Pharsalus , and roof Pharsalian seeking.
65.38: None will the fields now till; soft wax all necks the oxen,
65.39: Never the humble vine is purged by curve of the rake-tooth,
65.40: Never a pruner's hook thins out the shade of the tree-tufts,
65.41: Never a bull up-plows broad glebe with bend of the coulter,
65.42: Over whose point unuse displays the squalor of rust-stain.
65.43: But in the homestead's heart, where'er that opulent palace
65.44: Hides a retreat, all shines with splendour of gold and of silver.
65.45: Ivory blanches the seats, bright gleam the flagons a-table,
65.46: All of the mansion joys in royal riches and grandeur.
65.47: But for the Diva's use bestrewn is the genial bedstead,
65.48: Hidden in midmost stead, and its polisht framework of Indian
65.49: Tusk underlies its cloth empurpled by juice of the dye-shell.
65.50: This be a figured cloth with forms of manhood primeval
65.51: Showing by marvel-art the gifts and graces of heroes.
65.52: Here upon Dia's strand wave-resonant, ever-regarding
65.53: Theseus borne from sight outside by fleet of the fleetest,
65.54: Stands Ariadne with heart full-filled with furies unbated,
65.55: Nor can her sense as yet believe she 'spies the espied,
65.56: When like one that awakes new roused from slumber deceptive,
65.57: Sees she her hapless self lone left on loneliest sandbank:
65.58: While as the mindless youth with oars disturbeth the shallows,
65.59: Casts to the windy storms what vows he vainly had vowed.
65.60: Him through the sedges afar the sad-eyed maiden of Minos,
65.61: Likest a Bacchant-girl stone-carven, (O her sorrow!)
65.62: 'Spies, a-tossing the while on sorest billows of love-care.
65.63: Now no more on her blood-hued hair fine fillets retains she,
65.64: No more now light veil conceals her bosom erst hidden,
65.65: Now no more smooth zone contains her milky-hued paplets:
65.66: All gear dropping adown from every part of her person
65.67: Thrown, lie fronting her feet to the briny wavelets a sea-toy.
65.68: But at such now no more of her veil or her fillet a-floating
65.69: Had she regard: on you, Theseus! all of her heart-strength,
65.70: All of her sprite, her mind, forlorn, were evermore hanging.
65.71: Ah, sad soul, by grief and grievance driven beside you,
65.72: Sowed Erycina first those brambly cares in thy bosom,
65.73: What while issuing fierce with will enstarkened, Theseus
65.74: Forth from the bow-bent shore Piraean putting a-seawards
65.75: Reacht the Gortynian roofs where dwelt the injurious Monarch.
65.76: For 'twas told of yore how forced by pestilence cruel,
65.77: Eke as a blood rite due for the Androgeonian murder,
65.78: Many a chosen youth and the bloom of damsels unmarried
65.79: Food for the Minotaur, Cecropia was wont to befurnish.
65.80: Seeing his narrow walls in such wise vexed with evils,
65.81: Theseus of freest will for dear-loved Athens his body
65.82: Offered a victim so that no more to Crete be deported
65.83: Lives by Cecropia doomed to burials burying nowise;
65.84: Then with a swifty ship and soft breathed breezes a-stirring,
65.85: Sought he Minos the Haughty where homed in proudest of Mansions.
65.86: Him as with yearning glance forthright espied the royal
65.87: Maiden, whom pure chaste couch aspiring delicate odours
65.88: Cherisht, in soft embrace of a mother comforted all-whiles,
65.89: (E'en as the myrtles begot by the flowing floods of Eurotas,
65.90: Or as the tincts distinct brought forth by breath of the springtide)
65.91: Never the burning lights of her eyes from gazing upon him
65.92: Turned she, before fierce flame in all her body conceived she
65.93: Down in its deepest depths and burning within her marrow.
65.94: Ah, with unmitigate heart exciting wretchedmost furies,
65.95: You, Boy sacrosanct! man's grief and gladness commingling,
65.96: You too of Golgos Queen and Lady of leafy Idalium ,
65.97: Whelm'd you in what manner waves that maiden fantasy-fired,
65.98: All for a blond-haired youth suspiring many a singulf!
65.99: Whiles how dire was the dread she dreed in languishing heart-strings;
65.100: How yet more, ever more, with golden splendour she paled!
65.101: Whenas yearning to mate his might with the furious monster
65.102: Theseus braved his death or sought the prizes of praises.
65.103: Then of her gifts to gods not ingrate, nor profiting naught,
65.104: Promise with silent lip, addressed she timidly vowing.
65.105: For as an oak that shakes on topmost summit of Taurus
65.106: Its boughs, or cone-growing pine from bole bark resin exuding,
65.107: Whirlwind of passing might that twists the stems with its storm-blasts,
65.108: Uproots, deracinates, forthright its trunk to the farthest,
65.109: Prone falls, shattering wide what lies in line of its downfall,—
65.110: Thus was that wildling flung by Theseus and vanquisht of body,
65.111: Vainly tossing its horns and goring the wind to no purpose.
65.112: Thence with abounding praise returned he, guiding his footsteps,
65.113: While a fine drawn thread checked steps in wander abounding,
65.114: Lest when issuing forth of the winding maze labyrinthine
65.115: Baffled become his track by inobservable error.
65.116: But for what cause should I, from early subject digressing,
65.117: Tell of the daughter who the face of her sire unseeing,
65.118: Eke her sister's embrace nor less her mother's endearments,
65.119: Who in despair bewept her hapless child that so gladly
65.120: Chose before every and each the lively wooing of Theseus?
65.121: Or how borne by the ship to the yeasting shore-line of Dia
65.122: Came she? or how when bound her eyes in bondage of slumber
65.123: Left her that chosen mate with mind unmindful departing?
65.124: Often (they tell) with heart inflamed by fiery fury
65.125: Poured she shrilling of shrieks from deepest depths of her bosom;
65.126: Now she would sadly scale the broken faces of mountains,
65.127: Whence she might overglance the boundless boiling of billows,
65.128: Then she would rush to bestem the salt-plain's quivering wavelet
65.129: And from her ankles bare the dainty garment uplifting,
65.130: Spoke she these words ('tis said) from sorrow's deepest abysses,
65.131: While from her tear-drencht face outburst cold shivering sobs.
65.132: "Thus from my patrial shore, O traitor, hurried to exile,
65.133: Me on a lonely strand hast left, perfidious Theseus?
65.134: Thus wise farest, despite the godhead of Deities spurned,
65.135: (Reckless, alas!) to your home convoying perjury-curses?
65.136: Naught, then, ever availed that mind of cruelest counsel
65.137: Alter? No saving grace in you was evermore ready,
65.138: That to have pity on me vouchsafed your pitiless bosom?
65.139: Nevertheless not in past time such were the promises wordy
65.140: Lavished; nor such hopes to me the hapless were bidden;
65.141: But the glad married joys, the longed-for pleasures of wedlock.
65.142: All now empty and vain, by breath of the breezes bescattered!
65.143: Now, let woman no more trust her to man when he sweareth,
65.144: Ne'er let her hope to find or truth or faith in his pleadings,
65.145: Who when lustful thought forelooks to somewhat attaining,
65.146: Never an oath they fear, shall spare no promise to promise.
65.147: Yet no sooner they sate all lewdness and lecherous fancy,
65.148: Nothing remember of words and reck they naught of fore-swearing.
65.149: Certes, you did I snatch from midmost whirlpool of ruin
65.150: Deadly, and held it cheap loss of a brother to suffer
65.151: Rather than fail your need (O false!) at hour the supremest.
65.152: Therefore my limbs are doomed to be torn of birds, and of ferals
65.153: Prey, nor shall upheapt Earth afford a grave to my body.
65.154: Say me, what lioness bare you 'neath lone rock of the desert?
65.155: What sea spued you conceived from out the spume of his surges!
65.156: What manner Syrt, what ravening Scylla, what vasty Charybdis?
65.157: you who for sweet life saved such meeds are lief of returning!
65.158: If never willed your breast with me to mate you in marriage,
65.159: Hating the savage law decreed by primitive parent,
65.160: Still of your competence 'twas within your household to home me,
65.161: Where I might serve as slave in gladsome service familiar,
65.162: Laving your snow-white feet in clearest chrystalline waters
65.163: Or with its purpling gear your couch in company strewing.
65.164: Yet for what cause should I complain in vain to the winds that unknow me,
65.165: (I so beside me with grief!) which ne'er of senses endued
65.166: Hear not the words sent forth nor aught avail they to answer?
65.167: Now be his course well-nigh engaged in midway of ocean,
65.168: Nor any mortal shape appears in barrens of sea-wrack.
65.169: Thus at the latest hour with insults over-sufficient
65.170: E'en to my plaints fere Fate begrudges ears that would hear me.
65.171: Jupiter ! Lord of All-might, Oh would in days that are bygone
65.172: Ne'er had Cecropian poops toucht ground at Gnossian foreshore,
65.173: Nor to the unconquered Bull that tribute direful conveying
65.174: Had the false Seaman bound to Cretan island his hawser,
65.175: Nor had yon evil wight, 'neath shape the softest hard purpose
65.176: Hiding, enjoyed repose within our mansion beguested!
65.177: Whither can wend I now? What hope lends help to the lost one?
65.178: Idomenean mounts shall I scale? Ah, parted by whirlpools
65.179: Widest, yon truculent main where yields it power of passage?
65.180: Aid of my sire can I crave? Whom I willing abandoned,
65.181: Treading in tracks of a youth bewrayed with blood of a brother!
65.182: Can I console my soul with the helpful love of a helpmate
65.183: Who flies me with pliant oars, flies overbounding the sea-depths?
65.184: Nay, if this Coast I quit, this lone isle lends me no roof-tree,
65.185: Nor aught issue allows begirt by billows of Ocean:
65.186: Nowhere is path for flight: none hope shows: all things are silent:
65.187: All be a desolate waste: all makes display of destruction.
65.188: Yet never close these eyes in latest languor of dying,
65.189: Ne'er from my wearied frame go forth slow-ebbing my senses,
65.190: Ere from the Gods just doom implore I, treason-betrayed,
65.191: And with my breath supreme firm faith of Celestials invoke I.
65.192: Therefore, O you who 'venge man's deed with penalties direful,
65.193: Eumenides! aye wont to bind with viperous hairlocks
65.194: Foreheads,—Oh, deign outspeak fierce wrath from bosom outbreathing,
65.195: Hither, Oh hither, speed, and lend you all ear to my grievance,
65.196: Which now sad I (alas!) outpour from innermost vitals
65.197: Maugre my will, sans help, blind, fired with furious madness.
65.198: And, as indeed all spring from veriest core of my bosom,
65.199: Suffer you not the cause of grief and woe to evanish;
65.200: But with the Will wherewith could Theseus leave me in loneness,
65.201: Goddesses! bid that Will lead him, lead his, to destruction."
65.202: E'en as she thus poured forth these words from anguish of bosom,
65.203: And for this cruel deed, distracted, sued she for vengeance,
65.204: Nodded the Ruler of Gods Celestial, matchless of All-might,
65.205: When at the gest earth-plain and horrid spaces of ocean
65.206: Trembled, and every sphere rockt stars and planets resplendent.
65.207: Meanwhile Theseus himself, obscured in blindness of darkness
65.208: As to his mind, dismiss'd from breast oblivious all things
65.209: Erewhile enjoined and held hereto in memory constant,
65.210: Nor for his saddened sire the gladness-signals uphoisting
65.211: Heralded safe return within sight of the Erechthean harbour.
65.212: For 'twas told of yore, when from walls of the Virginal Deess
65.213: Aegeus speeding his son, to the care of breezes committed,
65.214: Thus with a last embrace to the youth spoke words of commandment:
65.215: "Son! far nearer my heart (you alone) than life of the longest,
65.216: Son, I perforce dismiss to doubtful, dangerous chances,
65.217: Lately restored to me when eld draws nearest his ending,
65.218: Since such fortune in me, and in you such boiling of valour
65.219: Tear you away from me so loath, whose eyes in their languor
65.220: Never are sated with sight of my son, all-dearest of figures.
65.221: Nor will I send you forth with joy that gladdens my bosom,
65.222: Nor will I suffer you show boon signs of favouring Fortune,
65.223: But from my soul I'll first express an issue of sorrow,
65.224: Soiling my hoary hairs with dust and ashes commingled;
65.225: Then will I hang stained sails fast-made to the wavering yard-arms,
65.226: So shall our mourning thought and burning torture of spirit
65.227: Show by the dark sombre-dye of Iberian canvas spread.
65.228: But, grant me the grace Who dwells in Sacred Itone,
65.229: (And our issue to guard and ward the seats of Erechtheus
65.230: Sware She) that if your right is besprent with blood of the Man-Bull,
65.231: Then do you so-wise act, and stored in memory's heart-core
65.232: Dwell these mandates of me, no time their traces untracing.
65.233: Dip, when first shall arise our hills to gladden your eye-glance,
65.234: Down from your every mast the ill-omened vestments of mourning,
65.235: Then let the twisten ropes upheave the whitest of canvas,
65.236: Wherewith splendid shall gleam the tallest spars of the top-mast,
65.237: These seeing sans delay with joy exalting my spirit
65.238: Well shall I wot boon Time sets you returning before me."
65.239: Such were the mandates which stored at first in memory constant
65.240: Faded from Theseus' mind like mists, compelled by the whirlwind,
65.241: Fleet from aerial crests of mountains hoary with snow-drifts.
65.242: But as the sire had sought the citadel's summit for outlook,
65.243: Wasting his anxious eyes with tear-floods evermore flowing,
65.244: Forthright e'en as he saw the sail-gear darkened with dye-stain,
65.245: Headlong himself flung he from the sea-cliff's pinnacled summit
65.246: Holding his Theseus lost by doom of pitiless Fortune.
65.247: Thus as he came to the home funest, his roof-tree paternal,
65.248: Theseus (vaunting the death), what dule to the maiden of Minos
65.249: Dealt with unminding mind so dree'd he similar dolour.
65.250: She too gazing in grief at the kelson vanishing slowly,
65.251: Self-wrapt, manifold cares revolved in spirit perturbed.
65.252: But from the further side came flitting bright-faced Iacchus
65.253: Girded by Satyr-crew and Nysa-reared Sileni
65.254: Burning with love unto thee (Ariadne!) and greeting thy presence.
65.255: Who flocking eager to fray did rave with infuriate spirit,
65.256: "Evoe" frenzying loud, with heads at "Evoe" rolling.
65.257: Brandisht some of the maids their thyrsi sheathed of spear-point,
65.258: Some snatcht limbs and joints of sturlings rended to pieces,
65.259: These girt necks and waists with writhing bodies of vipers,
65.260: Those with the gear enwombed in crates dark orgies ordained—
65.261: Orgies that ears profane must vainly lust for o'er hearing—
65.262: Others with palms on high smote hurried strokes on the cymbal,
65.263: Or from the polisht brass woke thin-toned tinkling music,
65.264: While from the many there boomed and blared hoarse blast of the horn-trump,
65.265: And with its horrid skirl loud shrilled the barbarous bag-pipe
65.266: Showing such varied forms, that richly-decorated couch-cloth
65.267: Folded in strait embrace the bedding drapery-veiled.
65.268: This when the Thessalan youths had eyed with eager inspection
65.269: Fulfilled, place they began to provide for venerate Godheads,
65.270: Even as Zephyrus' breath, seas couching placid at dawn-tide,
65.271: Roughens, then stings and spurs the wavelets slantingly fretted—
65.272: Rising Aurora the while 'neath Sol the wanderer's threshold—
65.273: Tardy at first they flow by the clement breathing of breezes
65.274: Urged, and echo the shores with soft-toned ripples of laughter,
65.275: But as the winds wax high so waves wax higher and higher,
65.276: Flashing and floating afar to outswim morn's purpurine splendours,—
65.277: So did the crowd fare forth, the royal vestibule leaving,
65.278: And to their house each wight with vaguing paces departed.
65.279: After their wending, the first, foremost from Pelion 's summit,
65.280: Chiron came to the front with woodland presents surcharged:
65.281: Whatso of blooms and flowers bring forth Thessalian uplands
65.282: Mighty with mountain crests, whate'er of riverine lea flowers
65.283: Reareth Favonius' air, bud-breeding, tepidly breathing,
65.284: All in his hands brought he, unseparate in woven garlands,
65.285: Whereat laughed the house as soothed by pleasure of perfume.
65.286: Presently Péneus appears, deserting verdurous Tempe —
65.287: Tempe girt by her belts of greenwood ever impending,
65.288: Left for the Mamonides with frequent dances to worship—
65.289: Nor is he empty of hand, for bears he tallest of beeches
65.290: Deracinate, and bays with straight boles lofty and stately,
65.291: Not without nodding plane-tree nor less the flexible sister
65.292: Fire-slain Phaëton left, and not without cypresses airy.
65.293: These in a line wide-broke set he, the Mansion surrounding,
65.294: So by the soft leaves screened, the porch might flourish in verdure.
65.295: Follows hard on his track with active spirit Prometheus,
65.296: Bearing extenuate sign of penalties suffer'd in by-gones.
65.297: Paid erewhiles what time fast-bound as to every member,
65.298: Hung he in carkanet slung from the Scythian rocktor.
65.299: Last did the Father of Gods with his sacred spouse and his offspring,
65.300: Proud from the Heavens proceed, thee leaving (Phoebus) in loneness,
65.301: Lone wi' thy sister twin who haunteth mountains of Idrus:
65.302: For that the Virgin spurned as thou the person of Peleus,
65.303: Nor Thetis' nuptial torch would greet by act of her presence.
65.304: When they had leaned their limbs upon snowy benches reposing,
65.305: Tables largely arranged with various viands were garnisht.
65.306: But, ere opened the feast, with infirm gesture their semblance
65.307: Shaking, the Parcae fell to chaunting veridique verses.
65.308: Robed were their tremulous frames all o'er in muffle of garments
65.309: Bright-white, purple of hem enfolding heels in its edges;
65.310: Snowy the fillets that bound heads aged by many a year-tide,
65.311: And, as their wont aye was, their hands plied labour unceasing.
65.312: Each in her left upheld with soft fleece clothed a distaff,
65.313: Then did the right that drew forth thread with upturn of fingers
65.314: Gently fashion the yarn which deftly twisted by thumb-ball
65.315: Speeded the spindle poised by thread-whorl perfect of polish;
65.316: Thus as the work was wrought, the lengths were trimmed wi' the fore-teeth,
65.317: While to their thin, dry lips stuck wool-flecks severed by biting,
65.318: Which at the first outstood from yarn-hanks evenly fine-drawn.
65.319: Still at their feet in front soft fleece-flecks white as the snow-flake
65.320: Lay in the trusty guard of wickers woven in withies.
65.321: Always a-carding the wool, with clear-toned voices resounding
65.322: Told they such lots as these in song divinely directed,
65.323: Chaunts which none after-time shall 'stablish falsehood-convicted.
65.324: O who by virtues great all highmost honours enhancest,
65.325: Guard of Emáthia-land, most famous made by thine offspring,
65.326: Take what the Sisters deign this gladsome day to disclose thee,
65.327: Oracles soothfast told,—And ye, by Destiny followed,
65.328: Speed ye, the well-spun woof out-drawing, speed ye, 0 Spindles.
65.329: Soon to thy sight shall rise, their fond hopes bringing to bridegrooms,
65.330: Hesperus : soon shall come thy spouse with planet auspicious,
65.331: Who shall thy mind enbathe with a love that softens the spirit,
65.332: And as thyself shall prepare for sinking in languorous slumber,
65.333: Under thy neck robust, soft arms dispreading as pillow.
65.335: Never a house like this such loves as these hath united,
65.336: Never did love conjoin by such-like covenant lovers,
65.337: As th'according tie Thetis deigned in concert wi' Peleus.
65.339: Born of yon twain shall come Achilles guiltless of fear-sense,
65.340: Known by his forceful breast and ne'er by back to the foeman,
65.341: Who shall at times full oft in doubtful contest of race-course
65.342: Conquer the fleet-foot doe with slot-tracks smoking and burning.
65.344: None shall with him compare, howe'er war-doughty a hero,
65.345: Whenas the Phrygian rills flow deep with bloodshed of Teucer,
65.346: And beleaguering the walls of Troy with longest of warfare
65.347: He shall the works lay low, third heir of Pelops the perjured.
65.349: His be the derring-do and deeds of valour egregious,
65.350: Often mothers shall own at funeral-rites of their children,
65.351: What time their hoary hairs from head in ashes are loosened,
65.352: And wi' their hands infirm thay smite their bosoms loose duggèd.
65.354: For as the toiling hind bestrewing denseness of corn-stalks
65.355: Under the broiling sun mows grain-fields yellow to harvest,
65.356: So shall his baneful brand strew earth with corpses of Troy-born.
65.358: Aye to his valorous worth attest shall wave of Scamander
65.359: Which unto Hellè-Sea fast flowing ever dischargeth,
65.360: Straiter whose course shall grow by up-heaped barrage of corpses,
65.361: While in his depths runs warm his stream with slaughter commingled.
65.363: Witness in fine shall be the victim rendered to death-stroke,
65.364: Whenas the earthern tomb on lofty tumulus builded
65.365: Shall of the stricken maid receive limbs white as the snow-flake.
65.367: For when at last shall Fors to weary Achaians her fiat
65.368: Deal, of Dardanus-town to burst Neptunian fetters,
65.369: Then shall the high-reared tomb stand bathed with Polyxena's life-blood,
65.370: Who, as the victim doomed to fall by the double-edged falchion,
65.371: Forward wi' hams relaxt shall smite a body beheaded.
65.373: Wherefore arise, ye pair, conjoin loves ardently longed-for,
65.374: Now doth the groom receive with happiest omen his goddess,
65.375: Now let the bride at length to her yearning spouse be delivered.
65.377: Neither the nurse who comes at dawn to visit her nursling
65.378: E'er shall avail her neck to begird with yesterday's ribband.
65.379: [Speed ye, the well-spun woof out-drawing, speed ye, 0 spindles.]
65.380: Nor shall the mother's soul for ill-matcht daughter a-grieving
65.381: Lose by a parted couch all hopes of favourite grandsons.
65.383: Thus in the bygone day Peleus' fate foretelling
65.384: Chaunted from breasts divine prophetic verse the Parcae.
65.385: For that the pure chaste homes of heroes to visit in person
65.386: Oft-tide the Gods, and themselves to display where mortals were gathered,
65.387: Wont were the Heavenlies while none human piety spurned.
65.388: Often the Deities' Sire, in fulgent temple a-dwelling,
65.389: Whenas in festal days received he his annual worship,
65.390: Looked upon hundreds of bulls felled prone on pavement before him.
65.391: Full oft Liber who roamed from topmost peak of Parnassus
65.392: Hunted his howling host, his Thyiads with tresses dishevelled.
65.393: Then with contending troops from all their city outflocking
65.394: Gladly the Delphians hailed their God with smoking of altars.
65.395: Often in death-full war and bravest of battle, or Mavors
65.396: Or rapid Triton's Queen or eke the Virgin Rhamnusian,
65.397: Bevies of weaponed men exhorting, proved their presence.
65.398: But from the time when earth was stained with unspeakable scandals
65.399: And forth fro' greeding breasts of all men justice departed,
65.400: Then did the brother drench his hands in brotherly bloodshed,
65.401: Stinted the son in heart to mourn decease of his parents,
65.402: Longèd the sire to sight his first-born's funeral convoy
65.403: So more freely the flower of step-dame-maiden to rifle;
65.404: After that impious Queen her guiltless son underlying,
65.405: Impious, the household gods with crime ne'er dreading to sully—
65.406: All things fair and nefand being mixt in fury of evil
65.407: Turned from ourselves avert the great goodwill of the Godheads.
65.408: Wherefor they nowise deign our human assemblies to visit,
65.409: Nor do they suffer themselves be met in light of the day-tide.

66.0: Albeit care that consumes, with dule assiduous grieving,
66.1: Me from the Learnèd Maids (Hortalus!) ever seclude,
66.2: Nor can avail sweet births of the Muses thou to deliver
66.3: Thought o' my mind; (so much floats it on flooding of ills:
66.4: For that the Lethe-wave upsurging of late from abysses,
66.5: Lavèd my brother's foot, paling with pallor of death,
66.6: He whom the Trojan soil, Rhoetean shore underlying,
66.7: Buries for ever and aye, forcibly snatched from our sight.
66.9: I can address; no more shall I hear thee tell of thy doings,
66.10: Say, shall I never again, brother all liefer than life,
66.11: Sight thee henceforth? But I will surely love thee for ever
66.12: Ever what songs I sing saddened shall be by thy death;
66.13: Such as the Daulian bird 'neath gloom of shadowy frondage
66.14: Warbles, of Itys lost ever bemoaning the lot.)
66.15: Yet amid grief so great to thee, my Hortalus, send I
66.16: These strains sung to a mode borrowed from Battiades;
66.17: Lest shouldest weet of me thy words, to wandering wind-gusts
66.18: Vainly committed, perchance forth of my memory flowed—
66.19: As did that apple sent for a furtive giftie by wooer,
66.20: In the chaste breast of the Maid hidden a-sudden out-sprang;
66.21: For did the hapless forget when in loose-girt garment it lurkèd,
66.22: Forth would it leap as she rose, scared by her mother's approach,
66.23: And while coursing headlong, it rolls far out of her keeping,
66.24: O'er the triste virgin's brow flushes the conscious blush.

67.0: He who every light of the sky world's vastness inspected,
67.1: He who mastered in mind risings and settings of stars,
67.2: How of the fast rising sun obscured be the fiery splendours,
67.3: How at the seasons assured vanish the planets from view,
67.4: How Diana to lurk thief-like 'neath Latmian stone-fields,
67.5: Summoned by sweetness of Love, comes from her aëry gyre;
67.6: That same Cónon espied among lights Celestial shining
67.7: Me, Berenice's Hair, which, from her glorious head,
67.8: Fulgent in brightness afar, to many a host of the Godheads
67.9: Stretching her soft smooth arms she vowed to devoutly bestow,
67.10: What time strengthened by joy of new-made wedlock the monarch
67.11: Bounds of Assyrian land hurried to plunder and pill;
67.12: Bearing of nightly strife new signs and traces delicious,
67.13: Won in the war he waged virginal trophies to win.
67.14: Loathsome is Venus to all new-paired? Else why be the parents'
67.15: Pleasure frustrated aye by the false flow of tears
67.16: Poured in profusion amid illuminate genial chamber?
67.17: Nay not real the 'groans; ever so help me the Gods!
67.18: This truth taught me my Queen by force of manifold 'plainings
67.19: After her new groom hied facing the fierceness of fight.
67.20: Yet so thou mournedst not for a bed deserted of husband,
67.21: As for a brother beloved wending on woefullest way?
67.22: How was the marrow of thee consumedly wasted by sorrow!
67.23: So clean forth of thy breast, rackt with solicitous care,
67.24: Mind fled, sense being reft! But I have known thee for certain
67.25: E'en from young virginal years lofty of spirit to be.
67.26: Hast thou forgotten the feat whose greatness won thee a royal
67.27: Marriage—a deed so prow, never a prower was dared?
67.28: Yet how sad was the speech thou spakest, thy husband farewelling!
67.29: ( Jupiter !) Often thine eyes wiping with sorrowful hand!
67.30: What manner God so great thus changed thee? Is it that lovers
67.31: Never will tarry afar parted from person beloved?
67.32: Then unto every God on behalf of thy helpmate, thy sweeting,
67.33: Me thou gayest in vow, not without bloodshed of bulls,
67.34: If he be granted return, and long while nowise delaying,
67.35: Captive Asia he add unto Egyptian bounds.
67.36: Now for such causes I, enrolled in host of the Heavens,
67.37: By a new present, discharge promise thou madest of old:
67.38: Maugrè my will, 0 Queen, my place on thy head I relinquished,
67.39: Maugrè my will, I attest, swearing by thee and thy head;
67.40: Penalty due shall befall whoso makes oath to no purpose.
67.41: Yet who assumes the vaunt forceful as iron to be?
67.42: E'en was that mount o'erthrown, though greatest in universe, where through
67.43: Thía's illustrious race speeded its voyage to end,
67.44: Whenas the Medes brought forth new sea, and barbarous youth-hood
67.45: Urged an Armada to swim traversing middle- Athos .
67.46: What can be done by Hair when such things yield them to Iron?
67.47: Jupiter ! Grant Chalybon perish the whole of the race,
67.48: Eke who in primal times ore seeking under the surface
67.49: Showed th' example, and spalled iron however so hard.
67.50: Shortly before I was shorn my sister tresses bewailèd
67.51: Lot of me, e'en as the sole brother to Memnon the Black,
67.52: Winnowing upper air wi' feathers flashing and quiv'ring,
67.53: Chloris' wing-borne steed, came before Arsinoë,
67.54: Whence upraising myself he flies through aëry shadows,
67.55: And in chaste Venus' breast drops he the present he bears.
67.56: Eke Zephyritis had sent, for the purpose trusted, her bondsman,
67.57: Settler of Grecian strain on the Canopian strand.
67.58: So willed various Gods, lest sole 'mid lights of the Heavens
67.59: Should Ariadne's crown taken from temples of her
67.60: Glitter in gold, but we not less shine fulgent in splendour,
67.61: We the consecrate spoils shed by a blond-hued head,
67.62: Even as weeping-wet sought I the fanes of Celestials
67.63: Placed me the Goddess a new light amid star-lights of old:
67.64: For with Virgo in touch and joining the furious Lion's
67.65: Radiance with Callisto, maid of Lyc´on beloved,
67.66: Wind I still to the west, conducting tardy Boötes,
67.67: Who unwilling and slow must into Ocean merge.
67.68: Yet though press me o'night the pacing footprints of Godheads,
67.69: Tethys, hoary of hair, ever regains me by day.
67.70: (Lend me thy leave to speak such words, Rhamnusian Virgin,
67.71: Verities like unto these never in fear will I veil;
67.72: Albeit every star asperse me with enemy's censure,
67.73: Secrets in soothfast heart hoarded perforce I reveal.)
67.74: Nowise gladdens me so this state as absence torments me,
67.75: Absence doomëd for aye ta'en fro' my mistress's head,
67.76: Where I was wont (though she such cares unknew in her girlhood)
67.77: Many a thousand scents, Syrian unguents, to sip.
67.78: Now do you pair conjoined by the longed-for light of the torches,
67.79: Earlier yield not selves unto unanimous wills
67.80: Nor wi' the dresses doft your barèd nipples encounter,
67.81: Ere shall yon onyx-vase pour me libations glad,
67.82: Onyx yours, ye that seek only rights of virtuous bed-rite.
67.83: But who yieldeth herself unto advowtry impure,
67.84: Ah! may her loathed gifts in light dust uselessly soak,
67.85: For of unworthy sprite never a gift I desire.
67.86: Rather, 0 new-mated brides, be concord aye your companion,
67.87: Ever let constant love dwell in the dwellings of you.
67.88: Yet when thou sightest, 0 Queen, the Constellations, I pray thee,
67.89: Every festal day Venus the Goddess appease;
67.90: Nor of thy unguent-gifts allow myself to be lacking,
67.91: Nay, do thou rather add largeliest increase to boons.
67.92: Would but the stars down fall! Could I of my Queen be the hair-lock,
67.93: Neighbour to Hydrochois e'en let Oarion shine.

68.0: 0 to the gentle spouse right dear, right dear to his parent,
68.1: Hail, and with increase fair Jupiter lend thee his aid,
68.2: Door, 'tis said wast fain kind service render to Balbus
68.3: Erst while, long as the house by her old owner was held;
68.4: Yet wast rumoured again to serve a purpose malignant,
68.5: After the elder was stretched, thou being oped for a bride.
68.6: Come, then, tell us the why in thee such change be reported
68.7: That to thy lord hast abjured faithfulness owed of old?
68.8: Never (so chance I to please Caeci1ius owning me now-a-days!)
68.9: Is it my own default, how so they say it be mine;
68.10: Nor can any declare aught sin by me was committed.
68.11: Yet it is so declared (Quintus!) by fable of folk;
68.12: Who, whenever they find things done no better than should be,
68.13: Come to me outcrying all:—"Door, the default is thine own!"
68.14: This be never enough for thee one-worded to utter,
68.15: But in such way to deal, each and all sense it and see.
68.16: What shall I do? None asks, while nobody troubles to know.
68.17: Willing are we? unto us stay not thy saying to say.
68.18: First let me note that the maid to us committed (assert they)
68.19: Was but a fraud: her mate never a touch of her had,
68.21: But that a father durst dishonour the bed of his first-born,
68.22: Folk all swear, and the house hapless with incest bewray;
68.23: Or that his impious mind was blunt with fiery passion
68.24: Or that his impotent son sprang from incapable seed.
68.25: And to be sought was one with nerve more nervous endowèd,
68.26: Who could better avail zone of the virgin to loose.
68.27: 'Sooth, of egregious sire for piety wondrous, thou tellest,
68.28: Who in the heart of his son lief was . . . !
68.29: Yet professed herself not only this to be knowing,
68.30: Brixia-town that lies under the Cycnean cliff,
68.31: Traversed by Mella-stream's soft-flowing yellow-hued current,
68.32: Brixia, Vérona's mother, I love for my home.
68.33: Eke of Posthumius' loves and Cornelius too there be tattle,
68.34: With whom dared the dame evil advowtry commit.
68.35: Here might somebody ask :—" How, Door, hast mastered such matter?
68.36: Thou that canst never avail threshold of owner to quit,
68.37: Neither canst listen to folk since here fast fixt to the side-posts
68.38: Only one office thou hast, shutting or opening the house."
68.39: Oft have I heard our dame in furtive murmurs o'er telling,
68.40: When with her handmaids alone, these her flagitious deeds,
68.41: Citing fore-cited names for that she never could fancy
68.42: Ever a Door was endow'd either with earlet or tongue.
68.43: Further she noted a wight whose name in public to mention
68.44: Nill I, lest he upraise eyebrows of carroty hue;
68.45: Long is the loon and large the law-suit brought they against him
68.46: Touching a child-bed false, claim of a belly that lied.

69.0: When to me sore opprest by bitter chance of misfortune
69.1: This thy letter thou send'st written wi' blotting of tears,
69.2: So might I save thee flung by spuming billows of ocean,
69.3: Shipwreckt, rescuing life snatcht from the threshold of death;
69.4: Eke neither Venus the Holy to rest in slumber's refreshment
69.5: Grants thee her grace on couch lying deserted and lone,
69.6: Nor can the Muses avail with dulcet song of old writers
69.7: Ever delight thy mind sleepless in anxious care;
69.8: Grateful be this to my thought since thus thy friend I'm entitled,
69.9: Hence of me seekest thou gifts Muses and Venus can give:
69.10: But that bide not unknown to thee my sorrows (0 Manius!)
69.11: And lest office of host I should be holden to hate,
69.12: Learn how in Fortune's deeps I chance myself to be drownèd,
69.13: Nor fro' the poor rich boons furthermore prithee require.
69.14: What while first to myself the pure-white garment was given,
69.15: Whenas my flowery years flowed in fruition of spring,
69.16: Much I disported enow, nor 'bode I a stranger to Goddess
69.17: Who with our cares is lief sweetness of bitter to mix:
69.18: Yet did a brother's death pursuits like these to my sorrow
69.19: Bid for me cease: Oh, snatcht brother! from wretchedest me.
69.20: Then, yea, thou by thy dying hast broke my comfort, 0 brother;
69.21: Buried together wi' thee lieth the whole of our house;
69.22: Perisht along wi' thyself all gauds and joys of our life-tide,
69.23: Douce love fostered by thee during the term of our days.
69.24: After thy doom of death fro' mind I banishèd wholly
69.25: Studies like these, and all lending a solace to soul;
69.26: Wherefore as to thy writ :—"Verona's home for Catullus
69.27: Bringeth him shame, for there men of superior mark
69.28: Must on a deserted couch fain chafe their refrigerate limbs:"
69.29: Such be no shame (Manius!): rather 'tis matter of ruth.
69.30: Pardon me, then, wilt thou an gifts bereft me by grieving
69.31: These I send not to thee since I avail not present.
69.32: For, that I own not here abundant treasure of writings
69.33: Has for its cause, in Rome dwell I; and there am I homed,
69.34: There be my seat, and there my years are gathered to harvest;
69.35: Out of book-cases galore here am I followed by one.
69.36: This being thus, nill I thou deem 'tis spirit malignant
69.37: Acts in such wise or mind lacking of liberal mood
69.38: That to thy prayer both gifts be not in plenty supplièd:
69.39: Willingly both had I sent, had I the needed supply.
69.40: Nor can I (Goddesses!) hide in what things Allius sent me
69.41: Aid, forbear to declare what was the aidance he deigned:
69.42: Neither shall fugitive Time from centuries ever oblivious
69.43: Veil in the blinds of night friendship he lavisht on me.
69.44: But will I say unto you what you shall say to the many
69.45: Thousands in turn, and make paper, old crone, to proclaim
69.47: And in his death become noted the more and the more,
69.48: Nor let spider on high that weaves her delicate webbing
69.49: Practise such labours o'er Allius' obsolete name.
69.50: For that ye weet right well what care Amathúsia two-faced
69.51: Gave me, and how she dasht every hope to the ground,
69.52: Whenas I burnt so hot as burn Trinacria's rocks or
69.53: Mallia stream that feeds Œtéan Thermopylae;
69.54: Nor did these saddened eyes to be dimmed by assiduous weeping
69.55: Cease, and my cheeks with showers ever in sadness be wet.
69.56: E'en as from aëry heights of mountain springeth a springlet
69.57: Limpidest leaping forth from rocking felted with moss,
69.58: Then having headlong rolled the prone-laid valley downpouring,
69.59: Populous region amid wendeth his gradual way,
69.60: Sweetest solace of all to the sweltering traveller wayworn,
69.61: Whenas the heavy heat fissures the fiery fields;
69.62: Or, as to seamen lost in night of whirlwind a-glooming
69.63: Gentle of breath there comes fairest and favouring breeze,
69.64: Pollux anon being prayed, nor less vows offered to Castor:—
69.65: Such was the aidance to us Manius pleased to afford.
69.66: He to my narrow domains far wider limits laid open,
69.67: He too gave me the house, also he gave me the dame,
69.68: She upon whom both might exert them, partners in love deeds.
69.69: Thither graceful of gait pacing my goddess white-hued
69.70: Came and with gleaming foot on the worn sole of the threshold
69.71: Stood she and prest its slab creakihg her sandals the while;
69.72: E'enso with love enflamed in olden days to her helpmate,
69.74: Sought, but in vain, for ne'er wi' sacrificial blood shed
69.75: Victims appeased the Lords ruling Celestial seats:
69.76: Never may I so joy in aught (Rhamnusian Virgin!)
69.77: That I engage in deed maugrè the will of the Lords.
69.78: How starved altar can crave for gore in piety poured,
69.79: Laodamia learnt taught by the loss of her man,
69.80: Driven perforce to loose the neck of new-wedded help-mate,
69.81: Whenas a winter had gone, nor other winter had come,
69.82: Ere in the long dark nights her greeding love was so sated
69.83: That she had power to live maugrè a marriage broke off,
69.84: Which, as the Parcae knew, too soon was fated to happen
69.85: Should he a soldier sail bound for those llian walls.
69.86: For that by Helena's rape, the Champion-leaders of Argives
69.87: Unto herself to incite Troy had already begun,
69.88: Troy (ah, curst be the name) common tomb of Asia and Europe,
69.89: Troy to sad ashes that turned valour and valorous men!
69.90: Eke to our brother beloved, destruction ever lamented
69.91: Brought she : 0 Brother for aye lost unto wretchedmost me,
69.92: Oh, to thy wretchedmost brother lost the light of his life-tide,
69.93: Buried together wi' thee lieth the whole of our house:
69.94: Perisht along wi' thyself forthright all joys we enjoyèd,
69.95: Douce joys fed by thy love during the term of our days;
69.96: Whom now art tombed so far nor 'mid familiar pavestones
69.97: Nor wi' thine ashes stored near to thy kith and thy kin,
69.98: But in that Troy obscene, that Troy of ill-omen, entombèd
69.99: Holds thee, an alien earth-buried in uttermost bourne.
69.100: Thither in haste so hot ('tis said) from allwhere the Youth-hood
69.101: Grecian, farèd in hosts forth of their hearths and their homes,
69.102: Lest with a stolen punk with fullest of pleasure should Paris
69.103: Fairly at leisure and ease sleep in the pacific bed.
69.104: Such was the hapless chance, most beautiful Laodamia,
69.105: Tare fro' thee dearer than life, dearer than spirit itself,
69.106: Him, that husband, whose love in so mighty a whirlpool of passion
69.107: Whelmed thee absorbed and plunged deep in its gulfy abyss,
69.108: E'en as the Grecians tell hard by Phenéus of Cylléne
69.109: Drained was the marish and dried, forming the fattest of soils,
69.110: Whenas in days long done to delve through marrow of mountains
69.112: What time sure of his shafts he smote Stymphalian monsters
69.113: Slaying their host at the hest dealt by a lord of less worth,
69.114: So might the gateway of Heaven be trodden by more of the godheads,
69.115: Nor might Hébé abide longer to maidenhood doomed.
69.116: Yet was the depth of thy love far deeper than deepest of marish
69.117: Which the hard mistress's yoke taught him so tamely to bear;
69.118: Never was head so dear to a grandsire wasted by life-tide
69.119: Whenas one daughter alone a grandson so tardy had reared,
69.120: Who being found against hope to inherit riches of forbears
69.121: In the well-witnessed Will haply by name did appear,
69.122: And 'spite impious hopes of baffled claimant to kinship
69.123: Startles the Vulturine grip clutching the frost-bitten poll.
69.124: Nor with such rapture e'er joyed his mate of snowy-hued plumage
69.125: Dove-mate, albeit aye wont in her immoderate heat
69.126: Said be the bird to snatch hot kisses with beak ever billing,
69.127: As diddest thou :—yet is Woman multivolent still.
69.128: But thou 'vailedest alone all these to conquer in love-lowe,
69.129: When conjoindd once more unto thy yellow-haired spouse.
69.130: Worthy of yielding to her in naught or ever so little
69.131: Came to the bosom of us she, the fair light of my life,
69.132: Round whom fluttering oft the Love-God hither and thither
69.133: Shone with a candid sheen robed in his safflower dress.
69.134: She though never she bide with one Catullus contented,
69.135: Yet will I bear with the rare thefts of my dame the discreet,
69.136: Lest over-irk I give which still of fools is the fashion.
69.137: Often did Juno eke Queen of the Heavenly host
69.138: Boil wi' the rabidest rage at dire default of a husband
69.139: Learning the manifold thefts of her omnivolent Jove,
69.140: Yet with the Gods mankind 'tis nowise righteous to liken,
69.142: Rid me of graceless task fit for a tremulous sire.
69.143: Yet was she never to me by hand paternal committed
69.144: Whenas she came to my house reeking Assyrian scents;
69.145: Nay, in the darkness of night her furtive favours she deigned me,
69.146: Self-willed taking herself from very mate's very breast.
69.147: Wherefore I hold it enough since given to us and us only
69.148: Boon of that day with Stone whiter than wont she denotes.
69.149: This to thee—all that I can—this offering couched in verses
69.150: (Allius!) as my return give I for service galore;
69.151: So wi' the seabriny rust your name may never be sullied
69.152: This day and that nor yet other and other again.
69.153: Hereto add may the Gods all good gifts, which Themis erewhiles
69.154: Wont on the pious of old from her full store to bestow:
69.155: Blest be the times of the twain, thyself and she who thy life is,
69.156: Also the home wherein dallied we, no less the Dame,
69.157: Anser to boot who first of mortals brought us together,
69.158: Whence from beginning all good Fortunes that blest us were born.
69.159: Lastly than every else one dearer than self and far dearer,
69.160: Light of my life who alive living to me can endear.

70.0: Wonder not blatantly why no woman shall ever be willing
70.1: (Rufus!) her tender thigh under thyself to bestow,
70.2: Not an thou tempt her full by bribes of the rarest garments,
70.3: Or by the dear delights gems the pellucidest deal.
70.4: Harms thee an ugly tale wherein of thee is recorded
70.5: Horrible stench of the goat under thine arm-pits be lodged.
70.6: All are in dread thereof; nor wonder this, for 'tis evil
70.7: Beastie, nor damsel fair ever thereto shall succumb.
70.8: So do thou either kill that cruel pest o' their noses,
70.9: Or at their reason of flight blatantly wondering cease.

71.0: Never, my woman oft says, with any of men will she mate be,
71.1: Save wi' my own very self, ask her though Jupiter deign!
71.2: Says she: but womanly words that are spoken to desireful lover
71.3: Ought to be written on wind or upon water that runs.

72.0: An of a goat-stink damned from armpits fusty one suffer,
72.1: Or if a crippling gout worthily any one rack,
72.2: 'Tis that rival o' thine who lief in loves of you meddles,
72.3: And, by a wondrous fate, gains him the twain of such ills.
72.4: For that, oft as he . . . , so oft that penance be two-fold;
72.5: Stifles her stench of goat, he too is kilt by his gout.

73.0: Wont thou to vaunt whilòme of, knowing only Catullus
73.1: (Lesbia!) nor to prefer Jupiter's self to myself.
73.2: Then, too, I loved thee well, not as vulgar wretch his mistress
73.3: But as a father his sons loves and his sons by the law.
73.4: Now have I learnt thee aright; wherefor though burn I the hotter,
73.5: Lighter and viler by far thou unto me hast become.
73.6: "How can this be?" dost ask: 'tis that such injury ever
73.7: Forces the hotter to love, also the less well to will.

74.0: Cease thou of any to hope desirèd boon of well-willing,
74.1: Or deem any shall prove pious and true to his dues.
74.2: Waxes the world ingrate, no deed benevolent profits,
74.3: Nay full oft it irks even offending the more:
74.4: Such is my case whom none maltreats more grievously bitter,
74.5: Than does the man that me held one and only to friend.

75.0: Wont was Gellius hear his uncle rich in reproaches,
75.1: When any ventured aught wanton in word or in deed.
75.2: Lest to him chance such befall, his uncle's consort seduced he,
75.3: And of his uncle himself fashioned an Harpocrates.
75.4: What so he willed did he; and nowdays albe his uncle
75.5: . . . .he, no word ever that uncle shall speak.

76.0: So in devotion to thee lost is the duty self due,
76.1: Nor can I will thee well if best of women thou prove thee,
76.2: Nor can I cease to love, do thou what doings thou wilt.

77.0: If to remember deeds whilòme well done be a pleasure
77.1: Meet for a man who deems all of his dealings be just,
77.2: Nor Holy Faith ever broke nor in whatever his compact
77.3: Sanction of Gods abused better to swindle mankind,
77.4: Much there remains for thee during length of living, Catullus,
77.5: Out of that Love ingrate further to solace thy soul;
77.6: For whatever of good can mortal declare of another
77.7: Or can avail he do, such thou hast said and hast done;
77.8: While to a thankless mind entrusted all of them perisht.
77.9: Why, then, crucify self now with a furthering pain?
77.10: Why not steady thy thoughts and draw thee back from such purpose,
77.11: Ceasing wretched to be maugrè the will of the Gods?
77.12: Difficult 'tis indeed long Love to depose of a sudden,
77.13: Difficult 'tis, yet do e'en as thou deem to be best.
77.14: This be thy safe-guard sole; this conquest needs to be conquered;
77.15: This thou must do, thus act, whether thou cannot or can.
77.16: If an ye have (0 Gods!) aught ruth, or if you for any
77.17: Bring at the moment of death latest assistance to man,
77.18: Look upon me (poor me!) and, should I be cleanly of living,
77.19: Out of my life deign pluck this my so pestilent plague,
77.20: Which as a lethargy o'er mine inmost vitals a-creeping,
77.21: Hath from my bosom expelled all of what joyance it joyed,
77.22: Now will I crave no more she love me e'en as I love her,
77.23: Nor (impossible chance!) ever she prove herself chaste:
77.24: Would I were only healed and shed this fulsome disorder.
77.25: Oh Gods, grant me this boon unto my piety due!

78.0: Rufus, trusted as friend by me, so fruitlessly, vainly,
78.1: (Vainly? nay to my bane and at a ruinous price!)
78.2: Hast thou cajoled me thus, and enfiring innermost vitals,
78.3: Ravished the whole of our good own'd by wretchedest me?
78.4: Ravished; (alas and alas!) of our life thou cruellest cruel
78.5: Venom, (alas and alas!) plague of our friendship and pest.
78.6: Yet must I now lament that lips so pure of the purest
78.7: Damsel, thy slaver foul soiled with filthiest kiss.
78.8: But ne'er hope to escape scot free; for thee shall all ages
78.9: Know, and what thing thou be, Fame, the old crone, shall declare.

79.0: Gallus hath brothers in pair, this owning most beautiful consort,
79.1: While unto that is given also a beautiful son.
79.2: Gallus is charming as man; for sweet loves ever conjoins he,
79.3: So that the charming lad sleep wi' the charmer his lass.
79.4: Gallus is foolish wight, nor self regards he as husband,
79.5: When being uncle how nuncle to cuckold he show.

80.0: Lesbius is beauty-man: why not? when Lesbia wills him
80.1: Better, Catullus, than thee backed by the whole of thy clan.
80.2: Yet may that beauty-man sell all his clan with Catullus,
80.3: An of three noted names greeting salute he can gain.

81.0: How shall I (Gellius!) tell what way lips rosy as thine are
81.1: Come to be bleached and blanched whiter than wintry snow,
81.2: When as thou quittest the house a-morn, and at two after noon-tide
81.3: Roused from quiet repose, wakest for length of the day?
81.4: Certès sure am I not an Rumour rightfully whisper

82.0: Could there never be found in folk so thronging (Juventius!)
82.1: Any one charming thee whom thou couldst fancy to love,
82.2: Save and except that host from deadliest site of Pisaurum,
82.3: Wight than a statue gilt wanner and yellower-hued,
82.4: Whom to thy heart thou takest and whom thou darest before us
82.5: Choose? But villain what deed doest thou little canst wot!

83.0: Quintius! an thou wish that Catullus should owe thee his eyes
83.1: Or aught further if aught dearer can be than his eyes,
83.2: Thou wilt not ravish from him what deems he dearer and nearer
83.3: E'en than his eyes if aught dearer there be than his eyes.

84.0: Lesbia heaps upon me foul words her mate being present;
84.1: Which to that simple soul causes the fullest delight.
84.2: Mule! naught sensest thou: did she forget us in silence,
84.3: Whole she had been; but now what so she rails and she snarls,
84.4: Not only dwells in her thought, but worse and even more risky,
84.5: Wrathful she bides. Which means, she is afire and she fumes.

85.2: What time flattering self he speaks with marvellous purity,
85.3: Clamouring "Hinsidious" loudly as ever he can.
85.4: Deem I thus did his dame and thus-wise Liber his uncle
85.5: Speak, and on spindle-side grandsire and grandmother too.
85.6: Restful reposed all ears when he was sent into Syria,
85.7: Hearing the self-same words softly and smoothly pronouncèd,
85.8: Nor any feared to hear such harshness uttered thereafter,
85.9: Whenas a sudden came message of horrible news,
85.10: Namely th' lonian waves when Arrius thither had wended,

86.0: Hate I, and love I. Haps thou'lt ask me wherefore I do so.
86.1: Wot I not, yet so I do feeling a torture of pain.

87.0: Quintia beautiful seems to the crowd; to me, fair, and tall,
87.1: Straight; and merits as these readily thus I confess,
87.2: But that she is beauteous all I deny, for nothing of lovesome,
87.3: Never a grain of salt, shows in her person so large.
87.4: Lesbia beautiful seems, and when all over she's fairest,
87.5: Any Venus-gift stole she from every one.

88.0: Never a woman could call herself so fondly beloved
88.1: Truly as Lesbia mine has been beloved of myself.
88.2: Never were Truth and Faith so firm in any one compact
88.3: As on the part of me kept I my love to thyself.
88.4: Now is my mind to a pass, my Lesbia, brought by thy treason,

89.0: What may he (Gellius!) do that ever for mother and sister
89.1: Itches and wakes thro' the nights, working wi' tunic bedoffed?
89.2: What may he do who nills his uncle ever be husband?
89.3: Wottest thou how much he ventures of sacrilege-sin?
89.4: Ventures he (0 Gellius!) what ne'er can ultimate Tethys
89.5: Wash from his soul, nor yet Ocean, watery sire.
89.6: For that of sin there's naught wherewith this sin can exceed he

90.0: Gellius is lean: Why not? For him so easy a mother
90.1: Lives, and a sister so boon, bonny and buxom to boot,
90.2: Uncle so kindly good and all things full of his lady-
90.3: Cousins, how can he cease leanest of lankies to be?
90.4: Albeit, touch he naught save that whose touch is a scandal,
90.5: Soon shall thou find wherefor he be as lean as thou like.

91.0: Born be a Magus, got by Gellius out of his mother
91.1: (Marriage nefand!) who shall Persian augury learn.
91.2: Needs it a Magus begot of son upon mother who bare him,
91.3: If that impious faith, Persian religion be fact,
91.4: So may their issue adore busy gods with recognised verses
91.5: Melting in altar-flame fatness contained by the caul.

92.0: Not for due cause I hoped to find thee (Gellius!) faithful
92.1: In this saddest our love, love that is lost and forlore,
92.2: Or fro' my wotting thee well or ever believing thee constant,
92.3: Or that thy mind could reject villany ever so vile,
92.4: But that because was she to thyself nor mother nor sister,
92.5: This same damsel whose Love me in its greatness devoured.
92.6: Yet though I had been joined wi' thee by amplest of usance,
92.7: Still could I never believe this was sufficient of cause.
92.8: Thou diddest deem it suffice: so great is thy pleasure in every
92.9: Crime wherein may be found somewhat enormous of guilt.

93.0: Lesbia naggeth at me evermore and ne'er is she silent
93.1: Touching myself: May I die but that by Lesbia I'm loved.
93.2: What be the proof? I rail and retort like her and revile her
93.3: Carefully, yet may I die but that I love her with love.

94.0: Study I not o'ermuch to please thee (Caesar!) and court thee,
94.1: Nor do I care e'en to know an thou be white or be black.

95.0: Mentula wooeth much: much wooeth he, be assurèd.
95.1: That is, e'en as they say, the Pot gathers leeks for the pot.

96.0: "Zmyrna" begun erstwhile nine harvests past by my Cinna
96.1: Publisht appears when now nine of his winters be gone;
96.2: Thousands fifty of lines meanwhile Hortensius in single
96.4: "Zmyrna" shall travel afar as the hollow breakers of Satrax,
96.5: "Zmyrna" by ages grey lastingly shall be perused.
96.6: But upon Padus' brink shall die Volusius his annals
96.7: And to the mackerel oft loose-fitting jacket afford.
96.8: Dear to my heart are aye the lightest works of my comrade,
96.9: Leave I the mob to enjoy tumidest Antimachus.

97.0: If to the dumb deaf tomb can aught or grateful or pleasing
97.1: (Calvus!) ever accrue rising from out of our dule,
97.2: Wherewith yearning desire renews our loves in the bygone,
97.3: And for long friendships lost many a tear must be shed;
97.4: Certès, never so much for doom of premature death-day
97.5: Must thy Quintilia mourn as she is joyed by thy love.

98.0: Never (so love me the Gods!) deemed I 'twas preference matter
98.1: Or Aemilius' mouth choose I to smell or his . . . .
98.2: Nothing is this more clean, uncleaner nothing that other,
98.3: Yet I ajudge . . . . cleaner and nicer to be;
98.4: For while this one lacks teeth, that one has cubit-long tushes,
98.5: Set in their battered gums favouring a muddy old box,
98.6: Not to say aught of gape like wide-cleft gap of a she-mule
98.7: Whenas in summer-heat wont peradventure to stale.
98.8: Yet has he many a motte and holds himself to be handsome—
98.9: Why wi' the baker's ass is he not bound to the mill?
98.10: Him if a damsel kiss we fain must think she be ready

99.0: Rightly of thee may be said, an of any, (thou stinkingest Victius!)
99.1: Whatso wont we to say touching the praters and prigs.
99.2: Thou wi' that tongue o' thine own, if granted occasion availest
99.3: Brogues of the cowherds to kiss, also their . . . .
99.4: Wouldst thou undo us all with a thorough undoing (0 Victius!)
99.5: Open thy gape :—thereby all shall be wholly undone.

100.0: E'en as thou played'st, from thee snatched I (0 honied Juventius!)
100.1: Kisslet of savour so sweet sweetest Ambrosia unknows.
100.2: Yet was the theft nowise scot-free, for more than an hour I
100.3: Clearly remember me fixt hanging from crest of the Cross,
100.4: Whatwhile I purged my sin unto thee nor with any weeping
100.5: Tittle of cruel despite such as be thine could I 'bate.
100.6: For that no sooner done thou washed thy liplets with many
100.7: Drops which thy fingers did wipe, using their every joint,
100.8: Lest of our mouths conjoined remain there aught by the contact
100.9: Like unto slaver foul shed by the butterèd bun.
100.10: Further, wretchedmost me betrayed to unfriendliest Love-god
100.11: Never thou ceased'st to pain hurting with every harm,
100.12: So that my taste be turned and kisses ambrosial erstwhile
100.13: Even than hellebore-juice bitterest bitterer grow.
100.14: Seeing such pangs as these prepared for unfortunate lover,
100.15: After this never again kiss will I venture to snatch.

101.1: Love to the death, both swains bloom of the youth Veronese,
101.2: This woo'd brother and that sue'd sister: so might the matter
101.3: Claim to be titled wi' sooth fairest fraternalest tie.
101.4: Whom shall I favour the first? Thee (Caelius!) for thou hast provèd
101.5: Singular friendship to us shown by the deeds it has done,
101.6: Whenas the flames insane had madded me, firing my marrow:
101.7: Caelius! happy be thou; ever be lusty in love.

102.0: Faring thro' many a folk and plowing many a sea-plain
102.1: These sad funeral-rites (Brother!) to deal thee I come,
102.2: So wi' the latest boons to the dead bestowed I may gift thee,
102.3: And I may vainly address ashes that answer have none,
102.4: Sithence of thee, very thee, to deprive me Fortune behested,
102.5: Woe for thee, Brother forlore! Cruelly severed fro' me.
102.7: Yet in the meanwhile now what olden usage of forbears
102.8: Brings as the boons that befit mournfullest funeral rites,
102.9: Thine be these gifts which flow with tear-flood shed by thy brother,
102.10: And, for ever and aye (Brother!) all hail and farewell.

103.0: If by confiding friend aught e'er be trusted in silence,
103.1: Unto a man whose mind known is for worthiest trust,
103.2: Me shalt thou find no less than such to secrecy oath-bound,
103.3: (Cornelius!) and now hold me an Harpocrates.

104.0: Or, d'ye hear, refund those ten sestertia (Silo!)
104.1: Then be thou e'en at thy will surly and savage o' mood:
104.2: Or, an thou love o'er-well those moneys, prithee no longer
104.3: Prove thee a pimp and withal surly and savage o' mood.

105.0: Canst thou credit that I could avail to revile my life-love,
105.1: She who be dearer to me even than either my eyes?
105.2: Ne'er could I, nor an I could, should I so losingly love her:
105.3: But with Tappo thou dost design every monstrous deed.

106.0: Mentula fain would ascend Pipléan mountain up-mounting:
106.1: Pitch him the Muses down headlong wi' forklets a-hurled.

107.0: When with a pretty-faced boy we see one playing the Crier,
107.1: What can we wot except longs he for selling the same?

108.0: An to one ever accrue any boon he lusted and longed for
108.1: Any time after despair, grateful it comes to his soul.
108.2: Thus 'tis grateful to us nor gold was ever so goodly,
108.3: When thou restorest thyself (Lesbia!) to loving-most me,
108.4: Self thou restorest unhoped, and after despair thou returnest.
108.5: Oh the fair light of a Day noted with notabler white!
108.6: Where lives a happier man than myself or—this being won me—
108.7: Who shall e'er boast that his life brought him more coveted lot?

109.0: If by the verdict o' folk thy hoary old age (0 Cominius!)
109.1: Filthy with fulsomest lust ever be doomed to the death,
109.2: Make I no manner of doubt but first thy tongue to the worthy
109.3: Ever a foe, cut out, ravening Vulture shall feed;
109.4: Gulp shall the Crow's black gorge those eye-balls dug from their sockets,
109.5: Guts of thee go to the dogs, all that remains to the wolves.

110.0: Gladsome to me, 0 my life, this love whose offer thou deignest
110.1: Between us twain lively and lusty to last soothfast.
110.2: (Great Gods!) grant ye the boon that prove her promises loyal,
110.3: Saying her say in truth spoken with spirit sincere;
110.4: So be it lawful for us to protract through length of our life-tide
110.5: Mutual pact of our love, pledges of holy good will!

111.0: Aufiléna! for aye good lasses are lauded as loyal:
111.1: Price of themselves they accept when they intend to perform.
111.2: All thou promised'st me in belying proves thee unfriendly,
111.3: For never giving and oft taking is deed illy done.
111.4: Either as honest to grant, or modest as never to promise,
111.5: Aufiléna! were fair, but at the gifties to clutch
111.6: Fraudfully, viler seems than greed of greediest harlot
111.7: Who with her every limb maketh a whore of herself.

112.0: Aufiléna! to live content with only one husband,
112.1: Praise is and truest of praise ever bestowed upon wife.
112.2: Yet were it liefer to lie any wise with any for lover,
112.3: Than to be breeder of boys uncle as cousins begat.

113.0: Great th'art (Naso!) as man, nor like thee many in greatness
113.1: Lower themselves (Naso!): great be thou, pathic to boot.

114.0: Pompey first being chosen Consul, twofold (O Cinna!)
114.1: Men for amours were famed: also when chosen again
114.2: Two they remained; but now is each one grown to a thousand

115.0: For yon Firmian domain not falsely Mentula hight is
115.1: Richard, owning for self so many excellent things—
115.2: Fish, fur, feather, all kinds, with prairie, corn-land, and ferals.
115.3: All no good: for th' outgoing, income immensely exceeds.
115.4: Therefore his grounds be rich own I, while he's but a pauper.
115.5: Laud we thy land while thou lackest joyance thereof.

116.0: Mentula! masterest thou some thirty acres of grassland
116.1: Full told, forty of field soil; others are sized as the sea.
116.2: Why may he not surpass in his riches any a Crœsus
116.3: Who in his one domain owns such abundance of good,
116.4: Grasslands, arable fields, vast woods and forest and marish
116.5: Yonder to Boreal-bounds trenching on Ocean tide?
116.6: Great are indeed all these, but thou by far be the greatest,
116.7: Never a man, but a great Mentula of menacing might.

117.0: Seeking often in mind with spirit eager of study
117.1: How I could send thee songs chaunted of Battiadés,
117.2: So thou be softened to us, nor any attempting thou venture
117.3: Shot of thy hostile shaft piercing me high as its head,—
117.4: Now do I ken this toil with vainest purpose was taken,
117.5: (Gellius!) nor herein aught have our prayers availèd.
117.6: Therefore we'll parry with cloak what shafts thou shootest against us;
117.7: And by our bolts transfixt, penalty due thou shalt pay.

edition:
Perseus:bib:oclc,878062, Catullus. Carmina. Sir Richard Francis
          Burton. trans. London. For translator for private use. 1894.
